Much more is known than you imply. It is absolutely clear that Dravidian languages diffused southward from the Indus Civilization and underlies Marathi, for example. What is not known is the languages in the south preceding the diffusiio of Dravidian, later Indo-Aryan languages-- such as the Vedda language that was in Sri Lanka. And there is aboundant archeology of the Indo-Aryan diffusiion from Central Asia into the Indus region and South Asia, also plenty of linguistic and other evidence of the origina development of Brahmanical type caste definition. Immerse yourself in South Asian studies and you will learn it
See Wendy Doniger The Hindus; An Alternative History for the details.

"People here are descendants of the Dravidians, before fair-skinned invaders came over the Himalayas and imposed the caste system, and British colonialism added another layer of color consciousness."

Gloria, this is a significantly outdated theory. It was largely conjured up by the British in the 19th century and was a convenient excuse for their colonial rule. In reality, there is absolutely no record of what happened that far ago, how the caste system came into being, indeed how and when the Dravidians (South Indians) and North Indians came to be in India respectively. A number of theories are bandied about, and though the consensus is on a migration (not invasion) from Central Asia into North India, the details are highly murky and there is no consensus on them.

An important, and entertaining, lesson I first learned from Khushwant Singh is that when doing business in a new country, first read the leading humorous, social commentator.  S/he will provide more insights into the commercial than all the business books combined.  I never learned more about doing business in India than from Khushwant Singh.

I had known Khushwant since we met in 1962 when I was a graduate student at Ann Arbor, where he and his wonderful wife Kaval, were visiting. Our professor had asked me and my late twin brother to drive them around and try to keep them happy when not doing planned things. What a joy!

It was the beginning of over 50 years of friendship I will always treasure. We were friends in Delhi when I was at the US Embassy and kept in touch albeit not often over the years. When I was in Delhi in 2008, I called his home to try to arrange a meeting but sadly, his age and loss of hearing made it impossible to do.

I will always remember his ironic sense of humor, his generosity and hospitality and serving him a rare steak and a glass of red wine when he came to my flat in Malcha Marg, New Delhi, to dinner.

I wish I could offer him a peg of scotch right now and toast old times. My sincere condolences to Rahul, Mala, and their families.

Murray Woldman, Alexandria, VA

Middle Class Indian, I agree with you that the divorce rate in India is rising. I disagree with your implied explanation that it is because women now have more options, and that therefore the increased divorce rate is a good thing - a good thing because women are able to leave marriages they are not happy with.

But it IS the sort of explanation that the Huffington Post would endorse and be happy with.

I am not sure that happiness is an objectively-verifiable indicator. It differs from the number of refrigerators per capita or the existence of outdoor toilets, the sorts of things which ARE objectively verifiable.

How can you know that someone is happy? You can tell by the smile on their face. But you do need eyes to see that smile, see past the objectively verifiable indicators.

It is interesting that many comments want minorities or women to tell others to "toughen up." Actually we are very tough. Microaggressions are day-to-day racialized slights that one really doesn't talk about. Such as when a restaurant hostess tells your white boyfriend that he's the first to arrive even though you are standing right there. Or in a hotel elevator, headed to your room and a white couple demands that you to get the valet to retrieve their car. Or when the new clerk at the club you've been a member of for decades requires further inspection of your ID and not that of your tennis partners. (These things have happened to me only in recent days, but I chalk it up to ignorance.)
Now, couple these microaggressions with overtly racist behavior, such as being followed around in stores. Or being pulled over (profiled) by the neighbor police officer when you drive your luxury car. Or being told that were denying a white person a job because of affirmative action in spite of your mile-long list of degrees and accomplishments.
Now, imagine dealing with this kind of dehumanizing behavior every day of your life and you'll realize that our skin is pretty thick.

As for Zo, the male attorney: The exact same 'brother and sister' comment has been made to me -by a black person. I'm quite white, the girl was too (this was twenty years ago). So shall I charge racism? Complain of offensiveness? No, it is actually a fond memory to me.

Being a woman I face an incredible number of macro and microaggressions every day.
I go into Home Depot and ask for a specific type of lag bolt and a teen-age boy asks me if I am sure that is what I need. I'm giving a 15 y/o boy a ride home (he is my next-door neighbor) and he tells me what exit to get off. I can't count the number of times that men have told me that I have done a lot in my life considering that I'm a girl! A girl at 65?
I tell someone I worked at Pearl Harbor and i am asked if my husband was in the military? I won my state amateur in golf and I can't make a tee time.
I used to get Sports Illustrated until their entire publishing empire revolved around their swimsuit issue. 65 y/o men are considered distinguished...I'm just old.
I was the only woman in pre-med in Utah and had a 96 percentile on MCATs and a 4.0 in Molecular Biology and was told by the board that I couldn't attend med school there because I would be taking the place of a man who needs to support his family...so I went to a Blue State.
I don't understand what being black is like. I only know that I have been a second class citizen my entire life since I happened to get an x chromosome from my dad instead of a y chromosome. I've been raped on 4 different occasions and was told it was my fault each time.
Geez I even went to Catholic School and was told in the second grade I couldn't be a priest! Why?? I was the top student. And many of my women friends feel exactly the same way.

I second the opinion of Korban from Lebanon, VT. I am a naturalized American who came from India 25 years ago. The immediate reaction to an article like this on micro-aggression is that it has all the makings of our worst fears about academia - sensitivity on steroids that make mountains out of molehills.

I get it. I really do. I mean, honestly, if we step back from this absolute standard of racial or ethnic equality and ask, how does America fare compared to other nations of even remotely comparable diversity, the answer is often resoundingly clear. America really is remarkably near, if not at, the top. It really must seem infuriating when the standard for sensitivity gets raised by seemingly whiny kids or professors or media. But hang on just a bit. Twenty years ago, compliments about my English made my day. But now, I have to admit, it makes me a bit uneasy. Maybe because it reminds me I am a foreigner still. How would my American son react to a similar compliment? Establishing his Americanness seems even more important to him and these compliments frustrate precisely that.

Perhaps such sentiments underlie those kids blogging about micro-aggressions. Try not to be too dismissive of it. After all, America is at the forefront of social progress and equality precisely because it is forever raising the bar on itself. It is what gives this country its ethos. Let's hear more on micro-aggression and all that. Let us let the issue percolate and see where it takes us.
Lot of mental chess being played here.  Lots of over-intellectualizing and nobody wins, everybody's scared and uptight and miserable.

"I would find it humorous to be confused with a waiter. What's the big deal? What's wrong with being a waiter?"

This is an example of either appalling ignorance or insensitivity. Given the legacy of how black people have been treated in this country for most of its history only a person totally ignorant of the fact that post slavery many black Americans were relegated to low paying jobs such as, servants, maids, cooks and waiters no matter what their abilities are educational accomplishments, would make a statement like this.

This is a perfect example of either an extreme level of racial insensitivity or an example of 21st century racism, which is acting in ways that are racist while declaring that no racism exists.

I agree that this stuff will occur so we have to learn to let it roll off us, but at the same time, I confess that I'm appalled at the cluelessness and insensitivity of so many of the comments here. There is an evident inability to understand how people who are subjected to stereotyping feel, or the demonstrated negative impact on their performance. And there is the usual offhand dismissal of the problems of others as insignificant, unlike, of course, the problems we ourselves face. That doesn't speak very highly of human nature.

If you can't handle microaggressions then you won't be able to survive in this world. If you look at any social situation, regardless of racial dynamics, you will see countless evil and petty people doing and saying awful things to each other and behind each others' backs. This is just how society works. Those who succeed are the ones who let this silliness role off their backs. I would find it humorous to be confused with a waiter. What's the big deal? What's wrong with being a waiter? The complaint itself is overtly classist.

Depends on the "sincere compliment," really. The issue is not typically a problem with the speaker's sincerity, nor with their desire to please. It's more often the belittling assumptions behind the compliment. The classic being, always and forever, "You're so well spoken."

"Your English is really good!"
"You're really pretty for a black girl."
"You're so exotic looking!"
"That's so amazing that you went to college!"

What still amazes me is not the "fantasy inside a delusion wrapped in a tissue of lies" paraphrasing Churchill's words as Madeleine Albright said yesterday, but the near neurotic need Russian authors have to be absolutely sure everybody else agrees with their delusional, sanctimonious double-speak? Staged referendums where people miraculously vote 97% for something are part of that long-standing, venerated Stalinist tradition, born out of a deep inferiority complex that still determines so much external behavior.

They have to be able to read and understand English and have an internet connection.  Their comments give us vision into what some Russians are thinking.  And even if it's all apparatchiks, it is still vision into what those apparatchiks are thinking.  I wish more Russians would comment.

What Mr. Ryan said resonated with me, as I have seen this directly with my own eyes. And while some of the people he describes are black, by no mans are they all. The culture in tailspin is very real, and there ARE generations of men now who are so cut off from the culture of work or responsible parenthood that there is no clear way to reclaim them. It certainly won't come about by raising the minimum wage by $3.

"Not so much? "
That's not at all!!
The low minimum wage demeans and insults people's humanity.

Paul Ryan undoubtedly tapped into prevailing stereotypes of poverty. Ryan didn't invoke racial identity in his remarks, but it's a virtual certainty that he intended for his words to evoke black, urban males.

The sad truth is that the budget and policy priorities that Ryan espouses have inflicted further hardship on poor Americans of all races by opposing a living minimum wage and supporting safety net cuts.

Work that pays a living wage promotes dignity. Work that fails this test, not so much.
And what happens when 100 rabbis change the rules?
Sorry, the civil courts in the US will not enforce religious aspects of divorce agreements between the adults of a marriage.

The moral of this story is that as part of the civil divorce settlement, both parties must do what is necessary to achieve the religious divorce, or, pay 100/day for every day that one party refuses to comply.  This is the only possible way to persuade a civil court to enforce a religious divorce.  As a matter of public policy, civil courts should not, in the absence of an agreement between the parties, get involved in religious divorces.

Ah, the Jets have made my life so much easier in terms of sports allegiances.  Goofy though it may be, I want all New York teams to be winners, but now it is easy to dump the Jets from my personal roster.  Do they really think that New York fans will forgive a guy who tortured dogs?  I don't want to hear about what happened in his miserable childhood.  Somewhere along the line he should have figured out the difference between right and wrong.  And so should have the Jets.  They brought him on for the greediest and most cynical of reasons.  Glad to not be conflicted again.  I hope the Jets remain losers.

All he's done is the mandated minimum so he can go back to a selfish lifestyle surrounded by and cheered on by sycophants. If not for people like me refusing to ignore his past, I have no doubt he would behave just as heinously again. It's complex, ACW. Judaism is not a top-down religion like Catholicism, so there are many branches, many rabbis and many interpretations of Talmudic law.

I assure you that it is not normal to see someone doing this in the Orthodox community or elsewhere; it is extremely bizarre. And yes, some details must have been left out.

It sounds like perhaps blackmail is involved, and that Mrs. Kin has some money or real estate assets that Mr. Kin wants to compel her to turn over to him. You cannot completely discount -- whether among the religious or among the completely non-observant -- the withering, soul-destroying effect that spite, bitterness and revenge can have on someone.

We do see this in other religions and among the secular -- the desire to hurt and keep hurting the ex-spouse and never move on. It can be through money, legal challenges, drawn out proceedings, vicious lies and smears -- and of course, Mr. Kin is hardly unique in using a remarriage as a way to strike back at his ex.

What makes this case unique -- and uniquely depressing -- is that the parties involved are supposedly deeply religious and spiritual people, who adhere to a dignified and longstanding religious tradition. Mr .Kin is making a mockery of his faith, in public, just to spite his ex-wife. It's very hard to imagine anything uglier (short of actual violence).

Have you ever had a pet? Dogs depend on us to be their caretakers. He perverted that human responsibility in the most grotesque ways. If there was any justice he would still be in prison right now for what he did.

From Juliet Macur's article about Vick's past: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/06/sports/football/before-signing-a-stron...
"Dogs that did not perform well for Vick were drowned, electrocuted, shot. He admitted to holding dogs while a noose was placed over their heads, then dropping those dogs to their deaths.

Once, he and a friend grabbed the paws of a little red dog and held it over their heads, like a jump rope, slamming the animal on the ground again and again until it was lifeless, according to “The Lost Dogs” by Jim Gorant, a book about the dogs in Vick’s ring."

It's a short step from the kind of animal cruelty to sociopathic behavior against his fellow human beings. Jets fans, I hope you're proud to have this monster on your team.

Mike, please. You are making false equivalences (actually, you are not comparing to anything, since saying "There are criminals all over the NFL" really doesn't mean anything).

Michael Vick murdered dogs. Is there a player on an NFL roster who is a murderer (i.e., dogs or any other living thing)? Compare like to like.

Someone who got caught with pot or was guilty of speeding may make them a criminal in your eyes (and I am guessing, since you do not state what your definition of a criminal is), but does not compare to what vick has done.

Yes, he paid his (minimal) debt to society, but has done nothing apparently to make up for the heinous crimes he committed (e.g., do charitable work in helping animals).
Its amazing reading the comments here. There are criminals all over the NFL. The fans couldn't care about the ones who hurt people just the one who hurt animals.
